page.title: 15ARCHITECTURE OF AREA
page.content: The lack of free stone in the area has meant that the older houses are timber framed. In the oldest examples split oak logs were used, but by Victorian times thinner sawn timber was common. The spaces between the timbers are filled with wattle and daub, or brick nogging. The coming of railways and tarred roads saw the greater use of brick,brought from Peterborough area. Today the Elizabethan brick houses (few) and timber framed houses form attracions for tourists. In the area there are no large modern housing estates, but there has been"infill"with high cost architect designed properties. Arkesden has many old houses surviving, making it a very pleasant but expensive village.
